entry.title: Structure and Function Pt. 4: Diving into Feature Design

link.title: Structure and Function Pt. 4: Diving into Feature Design

entry.content: Armed with an understanding of both the structure data ontology and function data ontology relevant to our visualization question, in conjunction the list of ideal interface characteristics mentioned in Pt 3, I began to dive into the feature design problem. If we were to develop an experiment selection interface for our data of interest (Rao et. al cell lines + related CHiP-seq experiments), what would this interface look like and how would it guide the user? Furthermore, what types of visual grammar explored in the background survey research could be leveraged to make clear relationships between heterogeneous genomics data types? The end goal of this step was to yield a prototype we could use to intitiate our iterative user testing process.

entry.title: Structure and Function Pt. 3: Building a Data Ontology

link.title: Structure and Function Pt. 3: Building a Data Ontology

entry.content:
Once we did a bit of work establishing the blind spots of current data repositories hosting structure and function data, we worked to crystallize the principles that would inform our newly developed organizational paradigm for storing, browsing, and visualizing collections of structure and function data. These principles were inspired both by the desire to go beyond currently available organzitional schema, as well as the desire to constrain our problem into a manageable enough scope to make the development of a prototype interface viable.

Visual Brainstorming

As I did research about CHiP-seq, conformation capture, and the various range of cell types that might populate our prototypical library, I kept a journal where I kept note of potentially useful organizational heuristics and sketched out my mental model of data ontology. Gradually pulling a visual schema out of this organizational thinking exercise connects to some of the higher level goals of this project for me, namely using visualization to traverse high dimensional data-spaces. Here are some of my initial notes:

And here are more notes. I specifically tinkered with how to create a visual model describing how structure data-space and function data space might interact with one another, and how the varying layers of complexity on each side might affect those interactions. Using this nested two-panel format to describe the data space and the challenges of navigating it ended up being a great tool for communicating with Noah about the mental models used to formulate structure-function hypotheses.

One crucial developmental point was coming to the conclusion that we needed ways to organize experiments both by what we know about them (e.g. attributes like phenotype, method, quality, date) as well as by direct computational comparison of experimental data which might capture similarity we don’t know about. It turns out many CHiP-seq experiments are done to capture binding affinities of proteins which have completely unknown function. If there is a protein with known function, and it has a similar binding pattern as a protein of unknown function, this a meaningful relationship we’d like to know about! Is there a way to make obvious such connections through a visual paradigm?

Organizing + Curating Structure Data

I tried to pin down actual quantitative measures of complexity that we would be dealing with when creating an interface to accomodate this ontology. One key constraint we decided on at this stage was to narrow our cell lines of interest to the 7 lines outlined in Rao et. al 2014, which is one of the most cited conformation capture experiments. The 7 cell lines for which Rao et. al 2014 has structural data are lines that have a plethora of functional experiments available (namely CHiP-seq), and furthermore the actual conformation capture done in this publication is regarded to be of very high quality. These data will be the inputs for researchers like Noah who experiment with various computational geometry techniques to generate polymer models of DNA, which constitute the actual structure files.

Techniques of generating 3 dimensional genomic structures from pairwise HI-C data and / or specific functional experiments have not converged at a consensus “best practice”. As such, there is a need to create a flexible organization scheme accounting for the fact that the majority of 3D structures are acquired directly from researchers experimenting with computational geometry rendering algorithms. Some algorithms render a single structure from a single Hi-C pairwise matrix; others render a population of structures using statistical methods across multiple Hi-C and functional reads. While each algorithm might be optimized for a specific use case by the researcher who designed it, no single algorithm can characteristize the provenance of 3 dimensional structure data in general. This is a stark contrast from the functional data, which we acquire from ENCODE after it has been standardized and quality controlled to a particular format. The biggest issue we see immediately on the structure side from a design perspective is to create a legible hierarchy that can grow and adapt as the techniques for rendering 3d structures become more nuanced and complete. This adaptability will allow structures generated from new algorithms to fit within our larger framework of ‘biologically meaningful’ structure-function matching.

Our structural hierarchy should look something like this quantitatively:

Organizing + Curating Function Data

Because we are interested in structure-function matches, we applied the same 7 cell line constraint from the Rao et. al 2014 paper that we used on the function side. In terms of experiment type, we are initially only going to look at organizational methods for CHiP-seq, since that seems to be the type with the largest amount of variety for our 7 cell lines. The most fine grained data type on the function side is the peak file, which is basically a histogram describing a variable quantity across the length of a genome. On ENCODE, it turns out just about every CHiP-seq experiment has multiple peak files, most of which are ‘replicates’ which ensure the reads are repeatable for a given experiment. While there are some time-dimensional experiments for which multiple peak files are an interesting level of data variety, we are going to constrain ourselves to 1 peak file per experiment to manage our complexity. Same as the CHiP-seq experiment type constraint, once we build the architecture to organize this, we might be able to expand it to accomodate more.

While there is more of an organizational pretext

Unifying Data Spaces

Bringing these two panels together as seen in the earlier notes helps us to illustrate the more nuanced conceptual problems of traversing current data repositories to observe interesting structure function relationships.

Noah referred earlier to an ideal interface being able to expose biologically meaningful matches between structure and function. Our visual model gives an idea of what types of complexity need to be wrangled in order to allow these matches. To continue our brainstorming we situated some of the challenges and complexities on the two panel model itself.

This framework for thinking about potential relationships between structure and function data allowed us to begin our iterative design process. At the heart of these issues was our actionable design question: what is the optimal way to pair a structure experiment and function experiment in an experiment browser that maximally facilitates exploration of the data space? The above issues constitute concrete obstacles to this exploration that we’d like to design around, and can largely be grouped into issues of data size, data heterogeneity, or clarity of metadata relationships. From here the next step was for me to dive into feature ideation to see what types of visualization methods we could leverage to get around these specific obstacles.

entry.title: Structure and Function Pt. 2: Data of Interest

link.title: Structure and Function Pt. 2: Data of Interest

entry.content:
After identifying the nexus of structural genomic data and functional genomic data as the problem space for which a visualization would ideally provide organization of knowledge, we had to pick some collection of datasets to impose our organizational regime. One of the first internet resources Noah pointed me to when explaining the problem of matching datasets was Cistrome dataset browser, which is a website that aggregates many types of next generation sequencing experiments on a variety of biological sources. Here’s a screenshot of Cistrome:

Noah showed me this dataset browser to give me an example of an organizational paradigm that was designed for targeted specific querying rather than exploratory querying. In the Cistrome broswer, the user has two options to narrow down the dataset library to find interesting groups of structural and functional data: select one of several hundred arcane propietary cell-line serial numbers, or from a list of ‘factors’ which identify binding sites of ChIP-seq experiments. While the cell-line serial and the ChIP binding factor are definitely identifying characteristics of an experiment, these characteristics are of little utility to a user who is perusing the library looking for interesting connections between datasets, without prior knowledge of how a given ChIP target or cell-line might be implicated in the context of a larger scientific hypothesis.

In the last post, I wrote about how Noah mentioned this library would be substantially more useful if it was organized in a biologically meaningful way, which provided heuristics for a user to narrow down these cell types and factors of interest. Evaluating Noah’s criticism of this particular interface drew my attention to the taxonomic aspect of this visualization challenge: how could visualization be leveraged to organize attributes like “source” and “factor” into useful mental models? Furthermore, how could these mental models allow for a navigation of structure/function data libraries in a way that facilitates hypothesis generation?

The next interface we explored was ENCODE. The level of organization is substantially superior to that of Cistrome. There are multiple filter types and organizational parameters that a user can leverage to find groups of experiments that are relevant to hypotheses involving heterogeneous genomic data types. Here is a screenshot of the ENCODE ‘experiment matrix’, which provides an overview of all the filtering parameters available to a user who might not know initially which specific experiment they are interested in:

This level of organization is great, but its emphasis on hosting data types for all types of genomics workflows makes it tricky to use for structure-function specific explorations of the data space. For starters, conformation experiments have only been done on around a dozen cell types–this experiment matrix shows so many cell types for which no conformation exists at all. Additionally, since there are so many different experiment types, there aren’t any filtering parameters that allow the user to sort through CHiP-seq experiments *. ENCODE’s lack of granularity in the CHiP binding target field unfortunately makes the 1000’s of CHiP experimments available for relevant cell lines as difficult to browse as the CHiP experiments in Cistrome. For structure-function research, this is particularly problematic because CHiP is one of the primary function experiment types users like Noah are interested in evaluating overlayed on structural data.

Working with Noah to identify why these currently existing resources are cumbersome clarified for me the type of data ontology an ideal experiment library interface would support. Just by looking at these two website we were able to identify some crucial desired characteristics:

  • biologically meaningful organization paradigm
  • support for organizing CHiP experiments
  • curated data showing experiments only for cell types that have an existing conformation capture
  • support for exploratory querying rather than specific querying

From this list of characterstics, I worked to develop a mental model that would inform our new organizational paradigm. The next post will document this development.

entry.title: Structure and Function: An Introduction
entry.content:
As mentioned in my introductory post, my culminatory work of this thesis project will be a portfolio of 3 design solutions to unique visualization challenges in genomics. One of these design projects is a collaboration with the Guttman Laboratory for lncRNA Biology, in which I will explore the creation of workflows for researchers interested in relationships between the physical structure of a genome inside a cell, and its functionality.

This project is an extension of some of the work I did this past summer as an intern in the JPL/Caltech Data Visualization Program. Over the summer, I worked with other interns and researchers at the Guttman Lab to understand the challenges involved in studying relationships between genomic structure and function. We learned that there are valuable insights to be uncovered through the analysis of DNA conformation data, but this analysis requires the navigation of very opaque and complicated datasets.

Basics of 3D Genomics

The 3 dimensional shape of DNA inside a cell consists of entanglements that occur across several orders of magnitude. The following graphic from Ea et. al 2015 shows the way 2 meters of DNA sequence are packaged into 5 microns of spherically confined space in the center of the nucleus.

Understanding the unique circumstances under which a sequence will fold in different ways is critical to understanding how cells can exhibit a diverse array of behaviors driven by the same sequence, and how defects in genome structure can cause cancer and many other disease. The process of coming to such an understanding is a multistage process. Researchers must dive into conformation capture datasets, which are stored in the form of massive adjacency matrices, to observe patterns of topological association between certain segments of DNA sequence. Areas of interest must then be cross referenced against expermental data which describes functional behavior of regions of DNA sequence. Other researchers approach this problem in the other direction: a particular bit of sequence is interesting for its functional characterstics, so they want to see how that region of sequence conforms in 3d space under certain conditions. The unification of structural and functional data allows the researcher to formulate models for the general principles that determine 3D genome structure and relationships between 3d genome structure and specific cellular function.

Creating a Workflow

Bringing these two types of datasets together in a way that facilitates analysis and developing a coherent workflow for meaningful hypothesis generation is currently very difficult. The main hurdles to such a workflow are:

  • The lack of tools to visualize and interact with 3D Genome structures. This was the subject of my summer work with the Guttman Lab which yielded Gin
  • The lack of any sort of organizational paradigm for the massive amounts of functional genomic data that can be mapped to structural information. This will be the challenge I intend to take on as a dedicated portion of my thesis project.

My collaborator at the Guttman Lab, Noah Ollikainen, elaborates further on this second point:

Current websites for accessing functional genomic data allow users to view gene expression data (RNA-seq) as well as find the DNA binding sites for proteins that regulate gene expression (ChIP-seq). A major challenge with using these websites is navigating the sheer volume of data, as RNA-seq experiments have now been performed in hundreds of different cell types and ChIP-seq experiments been performed for hundreds of different proteins. To access these data, a user must know exactly what they are looking for, e.g., the DNA binding sites of protein A in the genome of human cell-type B, and this severely limits our ability to perform exploratory research that enables novel discoveries.

An improved interface would organize these data in a biologically meaningful way. For example, these data could be organized hierarchically, where experiments in cell types derived from the same organ (e.g., liver, brain, kidney) are grouped together and experiments on proteins with a shared function (gene activator, gene repressor) are grouped together. Additionally, filters could be implemented to allow the user to restrict the data to a subset of interest, for example, cell lines derived from females only or data collected within the past N years. This organizational scheme would allow the user to easily select the most relevant functional genomic data for their research and explore the general relationship between these data and 3D genome structure.

Noah’s emphasis on exploratory research harkens back to the criteria of success I tackled in a previous blog post. One of the goals of genomic data visualization is to allow the exploration of complex data spaces in meaningful ways. In many cases, researchers don’t know what they are looking for, and look to visualization as a means for developing heuristics for narrowing down and identifying signficant features in these complex data spaces. The ideal workflow would combine methods of visualizing structure and methods of identifying functional data of interest to create a holistic understanding. entry.title: Genomics Visualization: Background & Prior Work
entry.content:
There are several different types of media that need to be explored to consolidate a history of prior work in genomics visualization.

  • media consisting of visualizations that describe a problem, process, or observation relating to genomic data.
  • media describing the problem space of visualization in genomics. this has to do with genomics’ place within the epistemological regime of systems biology
  • media that attempts to create criteria for good/bad visualizations

In this post I will tackle the first area. I’ve tried to select visualizations that I think are either effective or ineffective for notable reasons; there are a lot of bad visualizations out there so it is important to learn from ‘near misses’ instead of trying to extract meaning from something that is a complete failure.

This blog post by Mo Rahman, the founder of GeneDrop, provides a good overview of the most common types of visual grammar used in contemporary genomics problem solving. I want to elaborate on this overview of genomics visualization strategies by organizing visualizations by their functional goals in addition to just their overt appearance.

Track Visualization

Track visualizations present sequential information in a horizontal extended track, and are primarily utilized to examine issues of alignment between multiple sequences. The genome alignment problem space ranges from analyzing small varations in sequence amongst members of a population or species, to asking questions about complex conserved trends across species or generations. Given the scale and complexity of the variety of alignment relationships potentially of interest, it can be very trickly to legibly visualize an observation or a hypothesis. The following figure shows similarity and inversion of particular regions across 11 Lactobacillus genomes represented as tracks, from the paper “Tracing lifestyle adaptation in prokaryotic genomes”. It gets quite messy.

As such, researchers have explored custom track visualization solutions when a linear genome representation is required. A couple interesting examples include:

GeneDrop Custom Browser

This browser has been shown by Mo Rahman on Twitter and on his blog. It’s a custom in house genome browser used for informatics work at GeneDrop, and effectively shows how a well designed track visualization can frame the complexity at various levels of detail present in a multiple sequence alignment analysis. Here it is shown in a workflow for resolving structural variations in certain repetetive regions of genome sequence

and again here in an interesting post about analyzing strain variations of the ebola virus

Sequence Surveyor

This tool was developed at the Computer Graphics department at the University of Wisconsin-Madison as a scalable solution for comparing and clustering alignments. It uses gradients and cluster averaging to provide a way to compare multiple sequence alignments like in the Lactobacillus example, without the spiderweb of edges required to show congruence/inversion. This tool actually actually has interesting applications in text corpus analysis, but that is a discussion for a separate post.

BactoGENIE

This project is interesting because it unifies a hardware visualization solution with a custom visual grammar. BactoGENIE was created for visualizing metagenomic datasets, which are sequencing data taken from a variety of species populating a certain local biome (water in a lake, your intestines, etc.) Figuring out similarities between all the different types of bacterial DNA in the sample yields powerful insights about the stability and the history a local biomic environment. BactoGENIE runs on a large immersive display at the Experimental Visualization Laboratory at the University of Chicago

UCSC

The UCSC genome browser provides the most widely used and most accessible track visualization platform for genomic data. This project began to showcase the initial findings of the Human Genome Project, and continues to be a widely used repository for genomic alignment and annotation data for several different species. The UCSC browser actually combines data that are traditionally seen in heatmaps (such as measurement of gene expression, protein binding affinity, etc) along the distance of the sequence in addition to the tracks which indicate locations of genes/promoter regions for various species. While seeing these two types of information alongside each other can be very powerful analytically, the sheer quantity of informational tracks available on UCSC makes it difficult to explore potentially interesting patterns across a sequence. As such, the UCSC browser is used primarily to look up sections of sequence that have already been identified as noteworthy.

Heatmap Visualization

Heatmap visualizations are used for a variety of purposes in genomic analysis. When understanding the range of gene products created by a certain genome, researchers will use heatmaps to visualize patterns occuring in various forms of microarray data across specimens. This heatmap from Allard et. al 2012 shows clustered patterns of 66 transcripts differentially expressed between two populations in a cancer study.

IGV

The Integrative Genomics Viewer is a very widely used interface for aggregating and organizing heatmap data. It was created by the Broad Institute in 2011 to allow analysis of diverse datasets that annotate a genomic sequence across multiple scales.

Heatmaps are also used to show relationships of adjacency and connectedness. Additional explorations into microarray data like the one above look not only at how genes are differentially expressed amongst various specimens in an experiment, but how genes are coexpressed with other genes. In this way the heatmap is a reprojection of a graph whereby the rows and columns are the nodes and the color value in the cells represents strength of links. This graphic from Dewey et. al 2010 shows such a reprojection.

Another way heatmaps are used to project data about adjacency is in studies of chromosomal conformation. Recent technological breakthroughs have allowed researchers to capture the 3 dimensional structure of a genome inside a cell with higher degrees of confidence, and the visualization of this data is driving the study of how genomic structure affects its function. This graphic from Rao et. al 2014 utilizes heatmaps in such a way to explain folding of chromatin loops.

JuiceBox

Juicebox is a software for visualizing datasets that describe structural conformation of genomes. Like IGV, it provides dynamic rescaling of data at different zoom levels, which allows a user to observe interesting features across various orders of magnitude. It is currently one of the premier toolkits for structure-function research in genomics.

Tree Visualization

Visualizations describing the structure of biological classifications or ‘trees of life’ are amongst the most nascent forms of scientific visualization. Phylogenetic and taxonomic visualizations showcase evolutionary relationships amongst a population of biological entities. The visualized phylogeny provides useful information for a variety of populations, which could include microbial communities local to a biome, families of proteins present across species, or even more broadly defined groups in which relationships of common ancestry and heredity are of interest. Modern approaches to visualizing phylogenies typically utilize circular dendrograms, which provide increased space for more granular classification at the edges.

GraPhlAn

GraPhlAn is a genome phylogeny and taxonomy visualization package based around circular dendrograms. This particular figure from the GraPhlAn paper, Asnicar et. al 2015, demonstrates how the radial structure of the tree can be used to encode both information about hierarchy in a population of bacterial genomes, as well as functional attributes characterizing different regions of the genomic hierarchy.

Earlier in the paper the authors present this meta-diagram which demonstrates the process by which a dendrogram can be generated from a hierarchical data source. These types of meta-diagrams give an interesting peek into the construction of a design vocabulary for a given visualization problem, and will be covered more extensively in a future blog post.

Anvi’o

Anvi’o is a circular dendogram visualization designed as part of a metagenomics analysis pipeline. This pipeline is used to explore how genomic changes across multiple species in an environmental sample are related to broader environmental changes. The visualizations generated by Anvi’o are similar to the dendrograms seen in GraPhlAn, with a notable difference being Anvi’o is designed for encoding substantially more functional information by using the radial axis to represent time.

Network Visualization

There are a multitude of uses for network visualizations in genomics. Connectivity is a very important theme across genomics, and questions of connectedness are frequent avenues for interrogating a variety of different genomic data. As such, projection and reprojection of various types of genomic data into node-link space is common practice in contemporary genomic visual grammar. Furthermore, networks are intimately related to the epistemological task of genomics within the regime of systems biology: how do characterstics of the genome give rise to function and behavior of other biological systems?

Circos

Circos is a visualization package that is used to make a multitude of chord diagram based plots. Although it is purportedly agnostic to data source, it was designed as a utility for visualizing connectivity and adjacency in genomic data. I see the chord diagram as a reprojected heatmap. The following figure from Wei et. al shows a circos plot to describe connectivity amongst of group of protein kinases in maize. There are multiple types of functional annotation for each protein kinase visualized radially on the chord diagram as well.

Ayasdi

Networks visualizations can also be utilized as a low dimensional embedding of a clustering operation performed in high dimensional space. Ayasdi utilizes network visualizations to describe the results of topological data analysis performed on high dimensional data of various types. The figure here is comparing clustering of genomic expression profiles of various tumor biopsy samples. The relative shape and color of each network gives a viewer an idea of how similar any two tumors might be for a variety of different cancers. Between the node-link structure and the color gradient, a lot of information can be embedded in this visual style.

Valence

Valence was a design experiment that was part of Ben Fry’s Master’s Thesis: Organic Information Design. Valence sought to explore how networks can function as reprojections of linear sequences, and can potentially elucidate questions about connectedness of phrases that are not apparent in more traditional track based visualizations. It was utilized both on large corpuses of text as well as genomic data.

KEGG

From the Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes website, a KEGG pathway is desribed as a manually drawn map representing knowledge of molecular interaction and reaction networks linking data on genomics, transcriptomics, proteomics, and metabolomics. These pathway maps describe higher order systemic functions which implicate genomics into the larger descriptive paradigms of systems biology. While they do not provide the same type of exact mapping from data space to visual space that other modes of genomic visualization do, they are still very important as heuristic tools in systems biology. The following diagram is of KEGG pathway hsa01100, which describes the sum total of metabolic processes that drive human cellular activity.

Multi Visualization Suites

Sometimes being able to switch between multiple views of a dataset in succession is useful for understanding distributional characteristics and ascertaining significance of outliers.

Phinch

Phinch was created by the data visualization studio Pitch Interactive as a tool for visualizing high throughput metagenomic datasets, which contain genomic data from a variety of different organisms present in a local environment. In addition to providing a curated selection of plots to dive into a given dataset, particular attention is paid to providing a ‘designed’ data load in menu. Using data visualization to allow a user to identify which components of a vast data repository are to be visualized in further detail is a interesting and widely useful application of visual grammar in genomics.

Isometric Haplotype Blocks

Ben Fry designed this utility as part of his PhD thesis on computational information design. The study of haplotypes, which are groups of polymorphisms in the genome of a species that are often found together, is critical to understanding what types of genetic variation are related to disease. Understanding haplotype membership can be tricky, and requires identifying correlations amongst groups of polymorphisms in a population that pass a certain threshold known as Linkage Disequilibrium (LD). If there is no significant mechanism causing associations between polymorphisms in one region of a genome and another, population data should reflect that all combinations of polymorphisms in region A and region B are equally probable to occur in a specimen through normal genetic variation. However if region A and B are in strong LD, specific types of polymorphisms in region A are strongly correlated with specific polymorphisms in region B.

Fry’s visualization is an exercise in understanding how data on polymorphism and LD in a given population can help construct an idea of haplotype clustering for that population. By providing multiple isomorphic views of the dataset, the user can maintain context while considering different types of comparative evaluations of the patterns of polymorphism.
entry.summary: There are several different types of media that need to be explored to consolidate a history of prior work in genomics visualization.

entry.title: Geophysical Fluid Viewer
entry.content:
Description

This project was one of my primary efforts during the Summer 2016 Data Visualization Internship at the NASA Jet Propulsion Lab + Caltech. I worked with fellow interns Matt Edwards and Xiangjun Shi-Trofimov to create a visualization solution to explore some cutting edge research questions the Mark Simons lab has about interferometery based models of glacier flow. In order to develop better models for simulating glacier flow and to improve data collection techniques, researchers in the Simons lab wanted an integrated solution for visualizing information about the complex intereferometry data input into the flow model, and the output of that model. This flow model can have a multitude of components operating on vastly different time scales, so we had to create a visual grammar that would enable a user to look for potentially interesting flow characteristics or defects in the model across multiple scales. At the end of our 10 week program, our team came up with an interactive visualization prototype and an extensible design language for this challenging data space.

Process

Currently no interactive application exists for visualizing geophysical fluids with multiple geospatial and temporal layers. Matt, Xiangjun, and I decided to take a paper prototype approach to designing the interactions constituting the visualization app. We worked with Simons lab researchers to identify visual media such as 2d graphs, maps, and animations that clearly conveyed complex patterns in the interferometry data space, and leveraged the paper prototype process to figure out how elements from all these types of media could work coherently in a single visualization app.

Our final deliverable prototype was created in openFrameworks and provided a variety of interactive views. Through the process of designing our application we were able to introduce a lot of novel visual ideas to the Simons’ lab developers, and assess the viability of these ideas with the researchers.

entry.title: 3D Genome
entry.content:
Description

This project was one of my main efforts during the Summer 2016 Data Visualization Internship at the NASA Jet Propulsion Lab + Caltech. In collaboration with fellow intern Peter Polack, I worked with the Guttman Lab for lncRNA biology to devise a workflow for exploring complex datasets describing the 3 dimensional conformation of genomic data inside cells, so as to identify potentially interesting patterns. The recent increased availability of such structural datasets has many genomicists interested in studying relationships between genomic structure and function. During our 10 week program, Peter and I designed a coherent visual schema for representing and exploring structural genomic data in 3D and 2D, and created an interactive web-based prototype for scientists to visualize and explore structures using our paradigm.

Process

Currently, there are no standard tools used to visualize 3 dimensional genomic structures with functional annotations, so researchers in this novel data space resort to piecing together workflows with individual non-integrated software packages that visualize either structural data or functional data in 2D. Peter and I extensively interviewed different Guttman Lab researchers to identify roadblocks in their current data exploration workflows and created a conceptual model for a structure-function interface that would provide an integrated and intuitive experience for exploring interesting patterns in 3D structural genomic data. We also used these interview opportunities to explore various types of visual media our researcher collaborators found effective for describing and making obvious particular structural characteristics involved in their hypothesis testing processes. These discussions allowed us to develop novel interaction designs for our visualization that were absent in current toolsets, but intuitive to our researchers and consistent with the visual grammar they employ.

We used an iterative prototyping process leveraging both interactive prototypes and paper prototypes. The range of design materials Peter and I utilized in with the Guttman Lab researchers included paper storyboards, whiteboard sessions, 2d vector illustrated storyboards, and interactive javascript visualizations. Learning to move seamlessly between paper prototype materials and interactive digital prototypes as we progressed through the conceptual development of our data visualization solution was a central learning experience for me in this project.

I am currently extending this work as part of my thesis research at Carnegie Mellon centered around designing data visualizations for genomics. More information on my thesis and my exploration of the structure-function genomics data space can be seen on my blog

entry.title: Soylent Saviour
entry.content:
Description

This project was a collaboration with Aman Tiwari in Dana Cupkova’s Ecologics class. During the class we explored themes of parametric design and biomimicry, and we created this viewing apparatus as a culmination of our semester efforts. We were interested in the local cultural dynamics of the Pittsburgh technology/startup scene, and wanted to explore how use of data visualization and biological metaphor can create dialogue and reflection about the relationship between our tech community and the larger social ecology of Pittsburgh. We were also very inspired by Terreform One’s Bio City Map of 11 Billion and wanted to create an artifact that was not only a data visualization but a data driven organic ecosystem that locally simulates human social processes with bacterial + fungal life forms.

The result of our exploration was a physical map interface which combines robotic and organic components to present data about cultural change in Pittsburgh as a simulated fungal ecosystem. Viewers can observe data about tech investment, gentrification, and racial consolidation projection mapped across a transluscent agar topography of Pittsburgh, which also is host to slime mold spores located at technological epicenters in Pittsburgh. A robotic feeding system is fitted atop the topography and programatically feeds the spores through a servo actuated syringe which dispenses Soylent in one of two feeding patterns: either replaying historic data on tech investment in Pittsburgh or accepting interactive input from viewers. We invite viewers to compare the patterns of mold growth, tech investment, and gentrification superimposed upon one another in this map, and to think about how an influx of capital investment in “tech culture” can transform a local human ecosystem in both positive and negative ways.

Process

Our process on this project involved the design and fabrication of both software infrastructure and physical infrastructure. The first task we tackled was the collection of data to visualize. We met with members of tech incubators, CMU faculty involved with startup spinoffs, leaders of Pittsburgh technology trade organizations, and community activists to get a sense of which datasets we could put together to showcase a recent history of technology investment, gentrification, and socio-economic change in Pittsburgh. We ended up with an exhaustive list of tech companies in Pittsburgh, identifying their location and date they began to physically operate in Pittsburgh, as well as census block-resolution data about race, educational attainment, and income over the past 20 years. We iterated through both data sources and visualization methods when exploring how to map this data.

In parallel, we experimented with the visual mapping possiblities of mold growth, and observed how mold growth patterns change as a function of type and distribution of available nutrition. These experiments helped us understand how to integrate the mold into the overall composition of our map interface.

We then transmuted our visualization into a physical form by CNC milling and vacuum forming a topography of Pittsburgh, and creating an agar cast across this topography. I have created an Instructable explaining our pipeline for creating a physical agar cast topography from a shapefile and digital topography imagery.

Physarum Polycephalum slime mold spores were then placed at the epicenters of tech growth. Once the topography was complete and seeded, we assembled an acrylic + 80/20 aluminum frame as a viewing platform for the map and fitted the robotic feeding system above the map. To dispense the Soylent feeding solution, we designed and 3D-printed a mount to actuate a syringe with the servo motor built into the plotter head of the MakeBlock X-Y plotter.

Finally we connected the backend of our Javascript visualization to a node server controlling the plotter, which completed the interactive loop of the interface. Using the data coordinates showing tech businesses emerge over our 20 year timespan of interest, we fed the map to achieve an ‘initial state’ for interactivity. We then observed how the initial state patterns juxtaposed against projection mapping of race and gentrification data onto the agar substrate.

For more detailed information about these iterative steps, you can see our design documentation (WARNING: big .pdf!)

Recognition

Soylent Saviour was selected for presentation at ACADIA 2016, as part of the Contingent Landscapes project.

entry.title: Car Molecule
entry.content:
Description

This project is another instance of me looking to piece together creative workflows that involve tools that are traditionally used in a scientific context repurposed to an artistic end. I have been interested in the Molecular Maya plugin for some time now, which allows users to easily import complex molecular geometries into Maya for rendering of scientific art. I wanted to abstract away the underlying complexity and symmetry of a molecule and replace each instance of a particular molecule with some mechanical component, to create a form with underlying organic structural properties but with an outwardly mechanical appearance. The video shows a rendering of a particular nucleocapsid protein expressed in E. Coli with all its molecules replaced with pink Cadillac Escalades. This is my first foray into this territory and I intend to utilize this workflow I have discovered to piece to create many more of these forms in proper design study fashion.
